awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Building Highly-efficient and Low-power Edge Computing with Data-driven Learning and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things (IoT) is described as networks of small physical devices, embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies, that easily exchange data with other devices and systems over the Internet.  The convergence of traditional technologies from wireless networking, control systems, and automation with miniaturization and low-powered devices contributed to the development of IoT, spurred on by strong demand and rapid growth in smart home automation and smart cities.  Affordable interoperable IoT systems are increasingly ubiquitous in daily life.  These IoT devices, working closely together, orchestrate a range of tasks, increasingly used for such activities as programmable personalized control of heating, cooling, and security in homes and offices.  As these IoT devices become more capable, more computationally demanding tasks can be performed by these devices singly or in combination as a local distributed network bringing computing closer to the location where needed to improve responsiveness, i.e., at the edges of the Internet.  The challenge is to ensure the highly capable, timely performance, seamless collective operation of IoT devices with edge computing and even cloud services as an efficient purposeful system.

This project studies the relationships between system resource utilization and energy efficiency in various edge and IoT systems in order to better understand how to optimize the key performance parameters of edge computing systems. This project explores mitigating the inefficiency in edge systems through a data-driven approach.  Specifically, the primary research directions include: (1) analyzing the power inefficiency in different edge systems and develop a data-driven energy-aware framework for runtime edge and IoT applications, (2) tailoring the edge runtime framework including parts of data and control planes to reveal hidden dependencies, and (3) scaling and evaluating this framework and methodology in high-fidelity realistic test scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many key emerging areas, including edge computing and IoT, may face performance loss, low energy efficiency, and unstable service predictability if they only adopt traditional multi-layer cloud design. The difficulty lies in the highly correlated interactions between different system layers or components, including application diversity requirements, system resource utilization, and hardware energy consumption, as well as the inefficiency and inflexibility of edge data planes. This project aims to propose new system solutions to address these bottlenecks by re-examining the design constraints in various types of edge and IoT systems and developing practical prototypes for application in traditional edge systems and multiple new scenarios. Specifically, 

- It addresses the cold start in serverless computing and studies the performance, resource footprint, and energy consumption of representative artificial intelligence workloads on diverse edge devices.

- It focuses on the optimizations and improvements of representative edge workloads (e.g., virtual network functions (VNF) with 5G and drones, AI applications in traffic monitoring, etc.), and surveys the challenges and opportunities in next-generation edge computing platforms such as electric vehicles (EV).

- It further explores highly-efficient and low-power edge computing in multidisciplinary research, including (1) edge computing and AI in energy efficiency; (2) edge computing and electric vehicles; (3) edge computing and language models; and (4) edge computing and healthcare.

The intellectual achievement of this project is to systematically study the system resource utilization and energy efficiency in various types of edge and IoT systems and propose new methods to improve resource management and energy control through data-driven approaches. This significantly enhances the performance and resource efficiency of edge systems.The project has a wider impact in many aspects.

The research results have been disseminated through conference proceedings, journal articles, presentations, and open-source projects. The research outcomes of this project have been presented at multiple system conferences, including Cluster, IPCCC, ACMSE, TACO, and others, and have won the best paper award at DroneCom 2022. The program has supported several doctoral, master's, and undergraduate students, as well as women and underrepresented minority students, providing them with valuable research training. The research results have also led to the development and update of multiple undergraduate and graduate system-related courses at KSU.
